headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MAZZOLA, ANTHONY A.
summary: MAZZOLA--Anthony T., Former editor in chief of Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR, and the curator of Hearst Corporation's fine art collection, died May 21 in New York. He was 90. "Anthony Mazzola was a dynamic member of the Hearst Magazines family for more than 65 years," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. "Tony will be missed by everyone who had the pleasure of working with him." Frank A. Bennack, Jr., former CEO and now executive vice chairman of Hearst Corporation, added, "Tony Mazzola's contributions to Harper's BAZAAR and Town&Country have not only influenced those titles as they appear even today but our entire magazine business." Mazzola, the editor who defined affluence and style for millions of readers at the two magazines for 44 years, started his career at Hearst as an art director. In 1948, at the age of 25, Mazzola joined Town&Country as the youngest art director in the magazine's history. He held that post for nearly two decades, ultimately becoming editor in chief in 1965. Town&Country is the longest continuously published general-interest magazine in America, having been founded in 1846. "Tony Mazzola was one of the most creative editors I've known," said Hearst Corporation Director Gilbert C. Maurer. "A man of great personal style, he intuitively knew what good looked like and his work at Town&Country and Harper's BAZAAR reflected that acute sensibility. Tony was a loyal friend as well as a valuable mentor to a generation of our younger talents." Building on what he once described as his "fascination with trends," Mazzola's Town&Country began to reflect the current events and social reorganization then affecting elite American society as the nation mourned the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and grappled with civil rights, the Vietnam War and the first stirrings of modern-day feminism. Mazzola said he was captivated "not by what's happening, but why." While still the magazine's art director in 1964, he published a tongue-in-cheek "It's Fun to Be Rich" issue. In 1966, his first year as Town&Country's editor in chief, he put the Rolling Stones on the cover of what was widely held to be the bible of conservative, blue-blooded America. The ensuing controversy prompted Hearst's executives to ask him, "Young man, do you know what you're doing?" "I think so," he replied. In fact, Mazzola did: By maintaining a meticulous balance between creating an exciting magazine and conveying the dignity of the subjects he presented, he broadened Town&Country's appeal and honored its audience. "People make fun of money," he once said, "but everyone forgets the good that money has done." In 1972, Mazzola was appointed editor in chief of Harper's BAZAAR and expanded his editorial style even further. He relished the opportunity to widen the magazine's scope, which he again did in 1983 by adapting its pages to reflect newly emerging trends such as the more mature, sophisticated fashions--and celebrities--of the time, and readers' increasing interest in lifestyle, as well as fashion, content. "We love the handle of being the fashion magazine with a little salt and pepper added," he said of BAZAAR in a 1983 interview. "We appeal to a woman with a very strong confidence level, who is sure of herself, not wishy-washy. She wants to know everything there is to know...and we have become the fashion and beauty book with personality, the one with heart." At the end of the decade, Mazzola again redesigned the magazine, this time to appeal to readers as they matured from trendy to classic tastes. Striving for what he called a "very unconventional, exciting visual product," Mazzola encouraged photographers such as Francesco Scavullo, Rico Puhlmann and Matthew Rolston to take dramatic, even abstract approaches to fashion. One result was a celebrated shot described by a writer as "a woman and a cabbage leaf facing off" to illustrate a story on vegetable dyes used in hair coloring. After he stepped down as editor in chief in 1992, Mazzola edited BAZAAR's 125th anniversary book in 1993. The project was both professionally and personally rewarding. "Reliving the history of this great magazine and knowing that I had a role in it is a great privilege," he said. In 1995, he was editorial director of Town&Country's two-volume 150th anniversary book. Mazzola was also the fine arts curator for Hearst Corporation, whose fine art collection emphasizes works on paper and emerging talents, many of whom have become household names since the collection was started. In addition to curating and cataloguing the collection, he produced many art and photography shows for Hearst Tower. Mazzola graduated from The Cooper Union with honors in 1948 and received The Cooper Union's distinguished alumni citation in 1992. After beginning study at The Cooper Union, he was drafted into World War II. His art background prompted an assignment to army intelligence, where he analyzed camouflage. He was awarded a Bronze Star for "meritorious achievement in connection with military operations against the enemy in Luzon, Philippine Islands." A recipient of numerous awards in the art direction and design fields, Mazzola was inducted as a Knight Officer of the Order of Merit by the Republic of Italy in 1967. He also served as a consultant and designer for such organizations as the United Nations Children's Fund, the Association of Junior Leagues of America, Princess Marcella Borghese, Inc., General Foods, Columbia Pictures, Inc. and the New York World's Fair of 1965. Mazzola is survived by his wife, Michele Morgan Mazzola, who worked with him at Hearst for over 45 years, and three children, Alisa Mazzola Mitchell, Marc Mazzola and Tony Mazzola. He is also survived by five grandchildren. There will be a private funeral in Indiana, and a memorial in New York at a future date. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7105 or http://www.mskcc.org/giving).

headline: Google’s Video of Its Self-Driving Car
summary: The company has begun building a fleet of experimental electric-powered vehicles that can’t be driven by people and are summoned with a smartphone app.

headline: One Court Ruling on Privacy in Europe, and 28 Regulators
summary: Europe’s highest court defended its citizens’ right to privacy. But it left unstated what the channels and particulars are.

headline: Don’t Force Google to ‘Forget’
summary: But it does need to change how it searches for personal names.

headline: A Funny Name, a Serious Sport. Pickleball, Anyone?
summary: Nearly half a century since its creation, the tennis, table tennis and badminton hybrid is growing in popularity among baby boomers.

headline: Organizing Your Photos, Cloud-Free
summary: LyveHome has created a nifty way to arrange your photographs without using the cloud, but the system still needs a little smoothing out.

headline: Saving Your Favorite Videos on YouTube
summary: Plus how to back up an iPod Nano.

headline: Rackspace Hires Morgan Stanley to Explore Options
summary: Rackspace, a web-hosting company with a market value of more than $4 billion, has hired Morgan Stanley to evaluate a sale or other strategic options, after being approached by potential suitors.

headline: The Row’s New Home, a Frieze Frenzy and Moschino’s Plans for Men
summary: Plus, the social media response to anorexic mannequins, John Galliano’s next steps and more from the week in style.

headline: Yearning for a Bigger (Apple) Smartphone
summary: While I’ve owned an Apple iPhone for the past seven years, seeing a lot of larger Android devices on the market has caused me to have big phone envy.

headline: Ejected From the Doughnut Shop
summary: Metropolitan Diary: A customer felt sorry for a tall, shabbily-dressed woman who had been waiting silently until a store manager yelled at her to get out.

headline: Pepsi Challenges Coke in the Race to Design a More Tappable Soda Fountain
summary: With soda sales sliding in grocery and convenience stores and other retail outlets, new equipment offers the companies a means of introducing consumers to their products.

headline: Texas Chases New Business but Worries About Water
summary: A recent effort to lure a maker of the hot sauce sriracha from California came despite the challenges farmers face in a state where they have been given low priority for dwindling water supplies.

headline: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
summary: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.

headline: Reports of Gas Odors Surge After East Harlem Blast
summary: The number of calls to Consolidated Edison has led to a backlog of pipe repairs nearly twice as big as state regulators consider acceptable.

headline: Amazon vs. Hachette: When Does Discouragement Become Misrepresentation?
summary: Amazon promotes books from Hachette Books Group while discouraging people from buying them. After the retailer’s aggressive stance became public last week, criticism and complaints mounted. But Amazon seems confident it will get what it wants in the end.

headline: Portland, Ore., Sheds Its Walmart Bonds
summary: The city of Portland, Ore., said it had started divesting itself of holdings in the retail store because of its labor practices.

headline: AT&T Is Said to Be Near a Deal to Buy DirecTV
summary: AT&T is poised to announce a takeover, people briefed on the matter said on Saturday, ushering in another transformation of the telecommunications industry.

headline: Quixotic ’80 Campaign Gave Birth to Kochs’ Powerful Network
summary: David H. Koch, a 40-year-old bachelor living in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City, and his older brother Charles helped mount a long-shot assault on the fracturing American political establishment.

headline: Planners Adapt as Gay Unions Become More Common
summary: As same-sex marriages become more common, wedding planners are changing their game.

headline: Tackling the Limits of Touch Screens
summary: New products aim to remove the obstacles to reading and writing effectively on tablet computers.

headline: GreenTech Scatters New Seeds
summary: After the merger with VL Automotive, GreenTech Automotive promises to deliver a mix of electric city cars, plug-ins converted into muscle machines and performance-tuned cars for the Chinese market.

headline: What Do Pregnant Women Want?
summary: Their cravings and desires, unearthed in their online searches, are revealing.

headline: The Harmony They Want to Hear
summary: An Apple-Beats Electronics combination could jump-start two important industries: music and wearable technology.

headline: Children Don’t Belong in Tobacco Fields
summary: With children suffering from nicotine poisoning, Washington can’t just rely on the tobacco industry to police its suppliers.

headline: AT&T to Buy DirecTV for $48.5 Billion in Move to Expand Clout
summary: Under the terms of the deal, AT&T will pay about $95 a share in stock and cash to acquire the country’s biggest satellite television operator.

headline: Medicine’s Top Earners Are Not the M.D.s
summary: Overseeing the business of medicine is big business.

headline: Putting Drama to Work to Soothe
summary: The actor and writer Daniel Beaty tips his hat to Paul Robeson in a biographical play he created, but also follows his lead in working toward social change.

headline: AT&T Shareholders on Hold in DirecTV Deal
summary: The unexpectedly robust $1.6 billion of cost savings from the acquisition do not quite cover the 30 percent premium AT&T is paying, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: Verizon Wireless Names Faster Part of Its Network: XLTE
summary: The X refers to an extra-fast, higher-capacity version of LTE available on about half of Verizon’s network, including in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: How AT&T’s Deal for DirecTV Could Affect the Industry
summary: Several analysts thought the AT&T’s deal to buy DirecTV would pass regulatory muster, but some consumers and consumer advocates expressed concerns about the effects of reduced competition.

headline: The Curious Incident of Pfizer’s ‘Final’ Offer for AstraZeneca
summary: Britain does not have as many takeover defenses as the United States, so it is puzzling why Pfizer did not make a full-fledged hostile bid for AstraZeneca, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Betty Sherrill, Decorator to the White-Shoed and Wealthy, Dies at 91
summary: Mrs. Sherrill, a socialite from the South, was an arbiter of taste for New York’s bygone elite, known for her artful but conservative decorating.

headline: The Advisers Behind the Deal for DirecTV
summary: Even for the telecommunications industry, AT&T’s $48.5 billion bid for DirecTV is a blockbuster deal. And should it be completed, the deal could bestow a wealth of fees upon the advisers who worked on it.

headline: In Cannes, Who Needs the Movies?
summary: Parties, including the Vanity Fair gala, fashion shows and other events occupied celebrities near Cannes, leaving little time for the actual films.

headline: Drugs Found to Aid Breathing in a Fatal Lung Disease
summary: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis who were given pirfenidone or nintedanib declined more slowly, researchers in two studies reported.

headline: Camera Maker GoPro Files to Go Public
summary: GoPro is an unusual specimen for a Silicon Valley I.P.O., a hardware company without the flash of a social network or e-commerce start-up. The company said in the filing that it planned to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering, a figure that could change later.

headline: Cashless Customers Hold Riches for Retailers
summary: A hacking of customer data at Target has intensified the pace of changing the way Americans pay for goods.

headline: Options for Rivals in Wake of AT&T’s Bid for DirecTV
summary: Few industries have been as embroiled in merger mania as the telecommunications industry. Now, with another mega-deal in the works, how will others respond? Perhaps with even more consolidation.

headline: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Churns Regulatory Waters
summary: While AT&T’s bid for DirecTV bears similarity to Comcast’s deal for Time Warner Cable, experts say the differences could lead regulators to separate conclusions for each one.

headline: Taxi Commission Official Plans to Join Uber
summary: A top official at the Taxi and Limousine Commission, Ashwini Chhabra, is leaving for Uber, he said on Monday, becoming the company’s first head of policy development and community engagement.

headline: Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran’
summary: Six young Iranians were arrested and forced to repent on state television Tuesday for the grievous offense of proclaiming themselves to be “Happy in Tehran,” in a homemade music video they posted on YouTube.

headline: Daily Report: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Complicates Regulatory Task
summary: While AT&T’s bid for DirecTV bears similarity to Comcast’s deal for Time Warner Cable, experts say the differences could lead regulators to separate conclusions for each one.

headline: Mixed Signals in a Corporate Felon’s Punishment
summary: The government’s concern with minimizing the collateral consequences for Credit Suisse almost gives the impression that this was a guilty plea without all the guilt, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.

headline: Charges of Chinese Cyberspying, Wanted Posters Included
summary: The five members of China’s military accused of hacking against American companies are at the top of the F.B.I. “Cyber’s Most Wanted” list, but little has been revealed about them beyond their names and aliases.

headline: What AT&T’s Satellite Deal Might Mean
summary: The company has not yet made a convincing case that buying DirecTV will be good for consumers.

headline: AstraZeneca’s Shareholders Remain Sharply Divided Over Talks With Pfizer
summary: The fragmented response offers a glimmer of hope to Pfizer, but AstraZeneca also contends that under British takeover law, its hands are tied unless a third part steps in with a competing bid.

headline: Looking Overseas, Google Weighs a Shift in Deal Focus
summary: Google’s plan to reserve up to $30 billion of its cash for foreign acquisitions represents both a shift in its focus for mergers and the reality that the company keeps amassing money overseas.

headline: Google S.E.C. Filing Says It Wants Ads In Your Thermostat and Car
summary: According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Google wants to put advertisements on your thermostat, in your car and on your refrigerator.

headline: Remember to Forget
summary: Do you have to live with that goofy Instagram forever?

headline: Pfizer-AstraZeneca Talks Need a Rest and Then a Fresh Start
summary: If a merger with Pfizer really makes sense, AstraZeneca’s decision is not now or never, Christopher Hughes of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: Home Depot Leads Weak Retail Sector Ahead of Spring Spending Thaw
summary: The home improvement chain’s first-quarter sales increased 2.9 percent from a year earlier, but it joined a variety of other retailers in missing earnings expectations.

headline: California Urges Websites to Disclose Online Tracking
summary: The state’s attorney general is publishing guidelines meant to help companies comply with a new privacy law that went into effect Jan. 1.

headline: A Close Call for 2 Planes at Newark
summary: The National Transportation Safety Board reported that the pilots had to take evasive action to prevent a crash at Newark Liberty International Airport on April 24.

headline: Iranians Detained for ‘Happy’ Video Are Released on Bail
summary: One of the stars of “Happy in Tehran,” an exuberant music video that offended the sensibilities of Iran’s conservative judiciary, reported on Instagram Wednesday that she was free.

headline: Facebook’s New Privacy Mascot: The Zuckasaurus
summary: On Thursday, Facebook showed off a blue dinosaur character that will become the privacy ambassador on the social network. But the dinosaur could follow in the path of Microsoft’s Clippy, and Twitter’s Fail Whale, both of which were meant to help users and ended up being hated by people.

headline: Chromebooks Win Buyers Ready to Live in the Cloud
summary: Lightweight, inexpensive computers based on Google’s Chrome operating system are gaining acceptance as users learn to live in the cloud.

headline: BlackRock Encourages AstraZeneca to Renew Pfizer Talks at Later Date
summary: BlackRock, AstraZeneca’s largest shareholder, is said to prefer that the drug firm engage in talks with Pfizer later on rather than accept Pfizer’s most recent offer.

headline: Media Companies Join to Extend the Brands of YouTube Stars
summary: Keywords Press will release six to 10 titles annually, both in print and digital formats.

headline: One Woman’s Lonely Boycott of Amazon
summary: Amazon likes to say it is obsessed with its customers. It ranks high on the Reputation Institute’s annual survey of the most reputable companies. It’s also one of the hardest companies for customers to give up.

headline: A Survival Course for the Leaders of Companies in Pain
summary: Aileron, a nonprofit in Ohio, teaches business owners how to speed up their management learning curve and address issues that hurt their companies.

headline: Painless Shipping In a Few Easy Steps
summary: To ship through Shyp, you first download the firm’s iPhone app and enter in your payment data.

headline: As the Delay Continues on Crowdfunding Rules, Concerns About Investor Risks Grow
summary: Even one of the authors of the crowdfunding legislation wants the regulations tightened.

headline: Federal Regulators Seek to Stop Sale of Students’ Data
summary: ConnectEDU, a college and career planning site that collected student data, has proposed selling information as part of bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Sears Posts Worst Report of a Bad Lot in Retailing
summary: Sears Holdings’s dismal earnings report not only lacked signs of improvement but also laid bare how few options the company had left.

headline: Amazon’s Tactics Confirm Its Critics’ Worst Suspicions
summary: For years, Amazon’s critics have warned that the bookseller may flex its power once it controls the market for books. Now the company is proving its critics right.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 4
summary: We wrap up our look at fantasy-relevant rookies with players from the A.F.C. South and West, including Bishop Sankey and Marquise Lee.

headline: Elliott Management Backs Skyscraper Revival
summary: The $24 billion hedge fund run by Paul E. Singer is helping to finance the development of the site of one of Manhattan’s first skyscrapers.

headline: 2 Major Time Inc. Magazines Will Run Cover Advertising
summary: The ads, tiny strips running along the mailing label area, are to appear on the covers of Time and Sports Illustrated.

headline: Televising Sizzling Meat to Bump Up Sales of a Brisket Sandwich
summary: Arby’s filmed a brisket being smoked for 13 hours at the smokehouse in Texas that cures its brisket, and that footage will be one long commercial.

headline: Go Shop? Go Fish.
summary: The tactic of seeking bids after signing up a buyer is intended to ensure top dollar. More often, writes Reynolds Holding of Reuters Breakingviews, it leads to low offers and sale prices, new research shows.

headline: Tom Leighton of Akamai, on the Professorial Side of Leadership
summary: Mr. Leighton, chief executive of Akamai Technologies, considers the skills he learned as an academic essential to his position.

headline: Some Privacy, Please? Facebook, Under Pressure, Gets the Message
summary: The move responds to complaints that the service’s privacy settings are too complicated and that people often don’t know who can see what they’re posting.

summary: Seeking ever-higher payments from publishers to bolster its anemic bottom line, Amazon is holding books and authors hostage on two continents by delaying shipments and raising prices.

headline: European Regulators to Start Inquiry Into eBay Data Breach

headline: Cuban Talks His Way Onto a Limb Occupied by Sterling
summary: Mark Cuban, the owner of the Mavericks, sounded somewhat tone deaf while admitting that he harbors prejudice.

headline: Where Winners Play, and Losers Pay

headline: Global Digital News Brands See Growth Opportunity in India
summary: BuzzFeed, Huffington Post and Atlantic Media are among the companies with plans to build major online news operations in India, both on their own and with local partners.

headline: Faking Cultural Literacy
summary: Our cultural canon is determined by whatever gets the most clicks.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, May 25
summary: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.

headline: For Brett Wilson of TubeMogul, It’s All in the Follow-Through
summary: The chief executive of a video advertising software company says it values people “who do what they say — they have a high ‘do-to-say ratio.’”

headline: Q. and A.: Chan Koonchung on Tibet, Sex and Censorship
summary: The author’s latest novel, “The Unbearable Dreamworld of Champa the Driver,” about a young Tibetan trying to find his way in Beijing, was published in English this month.

headline: My T-Shirt Told Me to Take a Chill Pill
summary: Smart textiles are starting to hit the market. Their fans say they could represent the future of wearable computing.

headline: No Time to Text? Say It With Stickers

headline: The Economy, Explored on Film

summary: Mr. Woods, a marketer and lifelong entrepreneur, put Sonoma County grapes on the map with his Clos du Bois winery.

headline: Rebutting Mark Cuban on Bigotry
summary: He gets points for candor, but the conversation can’t end there.

headline: Dairy Queen Finds a Summer Love: The S’more
summary: The company’s new ad campaign focuses on limited-time offers, including the S’mores Blizzard, returning from last summer, and a second item, the Chips Ahoy Blizzard, new for this summer.

headline: A Site That Matches Hotels With Prospective Guests

headline: Twitter’s Growth Shifts to Developing Countries

headline: Threatening a Proxy Battle, Valeant Raises Its Offer on the Botox Maker Allergan

summary: In its pursuit of the maker of Botox, Valeant Pharmaceuticals has more work to do to reclaim the role of aggressor, writes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Even Sun Microsystems Had Its Roots at Xerox PARC

summary: Made with natural oak and brass, the house’s newest offerings will find a place in almost any home.

headline: Goldman Predicts Brazil Will Win the 2014 World Cup

headline: Daily Report: Google Testing a Completely Driverless Car
summary: Google has begun building a fleet of 100 experimental electric-powered vehicles that will dispense with all the standard controls found in modern automobiles and take the driver out of driving.

headline: Making Twitter Easier to Use
summary: Dick Costolo, chief executive of the social network, said Twitter is trying to make its service easier to use, including using a mix of human curation and more sophisticated computer formulas to showcase the most relevant posts for each individual.

summary: Google has begun building a fleet of 100 experimental electric-powered vehicles that will dispense with all the standard controls found in modern automobiles and take the driver out of driving.

headline: New Curbs Sought on the Personal Data Industry
summary: The Federal Trade Commission said consumers should have access to information collected about them, along with the ability to suppress information.

headline: Apple to Pay $3 Billion to Buy Beats

summary: Apple is betting that Mr. Iovine’s four decades in the recording industry, his knack for trend-spotting and his credibility with artists will help rejuvenate its music business.

headline: Dish Network Says It Will Accept Bitcoin
summary: The satellite television provider announced on Thursday that it will begin allowing its 14 million subscribers to pay in Bitcoin later this year.

summary: In acquiring Beats Electronics, Apple is hoping that its co-founder, Jimmy Iovine, will help Apple rejuvenate its music business nearly three years after the death of Steven P. Jobs.

summary: A series of attacks against American defense contractors, lobbyists, journalists and congressional personnel has been traced to hackers in Iran.

summary: Plus, how to use use your 4G iPad as a mobile hot spot.

headline: If You Work in Silicon Valley, Odds Are You’re a Man
summary: Google releases figures showing just 17 percent of its technical employees are women and just 1 percent are black.

summary: The music impresario Jimmy Iovine, who agreed to sell Beats Electronics to Apple for $3 billion on Wednesday, pulled no punches as he talked about his new employer, the competition and Silicon Valley.

headline: Samsung Stakes Claim on Wearable Tech That Monitors Health
summary: Samsung’s innovation and strategy team announced plans for an “open” platform so that developers, medical professionals and hardware makers can push forward the idea of “intelligent digital health.”

headline: The Flaws of Apple’s iMessage
summary: Because the service comes installed on iPhones, and in my experience is turned on by default, it is hugely popular. But there are many good alternative services.

summary: Although there was no confirmation of the number of bidding groups, a person involved in the proposed sale said that Rochelle Sterling hopes to choose a buyer over the weekend.

headline: Hachette and Amazon Dig In for a Long Fight Over Contract Terms
summary: The only thing the publisher and the retailer agree on is that there is no deal in sight, and 5,000 Hachette books are caught in the middle.

headline: Underscoring Success of Live TV, Music Specials Will Make a Return
summary: The revival dovetails with a growing programming trend: a desire among networks to give viewers more shows deemed worth watching — and discussing on social media — in real time, making it likelier that commercials will be seen.

headline: Daily Report: Hurdles to Privacy on Web in Europe
summary: A recent court ruling in Europe has accelerated requests that Internet search companies expunge individuals’ data. Once a contested item is online, however, the genie will not easily go back in the bottle.

summary: A recent court ruling in Europe has accelerated requests that Internet search companies remove links to individuals’ data. Once a contested item is online, however, the genie will not easily go back in the bottle.

headline: More Emergency Centers Are Gearing Up to Receive 911 Texts
summary: Texas is at the forefront of a national initiative to modernize the call system to accommodate situations in which a voice call may be risky or impossible and to be more accessible to the deaf community.

headline: Brad Jefferson of Animoto, on Knowing Your Company’s Heartbeat
summary: The chief executive of Animoto, a video slide show service, answers all the questions that his employees submit anonymously each month — even the hard ones.

headline: What the Beats Deal Says About Apple: It Loves Tastemakers
summary: If Silicon Valley is bent on replacing human judgment with algorithmic efficiency, the Beats deal shows that Apple wants to hold itself up as the one tech company that stands proudly against that trend.

headline: Keeping Windows 8.1 Up to Date
summary: Plus, how to move from Windows XP to a Mac.

headline: Fine Legal Point Poses Challenge to Appraisal Rights
summary: The question of whether a shareholder can prove it did not vote in favor of a takeover before asserting its appraisal rights could present a significant hurdle to hedge funds that have adopted such rights as a business strategy, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Malcolm Gladwell ‘Surprised’ to Become an Amazon Bargaining Chip

summary: Amazon used to take margin from its suppliers so it could sell things more cheaply. Now, it needs the margin for itself.

headline: Director of ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Is Reportedly Freed

headline: Iran Hackers Dangle a Familiar Name to Fish for Data
summary: Hackers seeking information about Washington’s elite posed as John R. Bolton, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, to friend online users through social media.

headline: Urban Renewal, No Bulldozer
summary: Businesses are planting themselves in existing buildings in San Francisco, while residents are getting little relief from the high housing costs, and new construction faces obstructions.

headline: All Paths Lead to Illumination
summary: “Mastering Light: From the Natural to the Artificial” at Vassar’s Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center in Poughkeepsie is a quirky, thought-provoking show that divides its subject into three sometimes overlapping areas.

headline: Mapping Apps Follow the Crowd
summary: Telenav, a navigation services company, is switching from maps that are professionally produced to ones that are crowdsourced, using data and updates provided by contributors.
